## Header: Modelling Methodology
h3("Purpose",style=c("color:#044D94"))
p("This app provides modelled layers for different aspects of benthic biodiversity. Models are based on ",tags$a(href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_forest", "random forest") ," modelling of point sample data from the ",tags$a(href="https://sway.office.com/HM5VkWvBoZ86atYP?ref=Link/", "OneBenthic")," big data initiative (see below for a non-technical summary of the modelling methodology).  Understanding of benthic biodiversity is vital for effective decision concerning marine spatial planning, marine licensing, conservation, ",tags$a(href="https://www.marine-ecosystems.org.uk/Research_outcomes/Natural_Capital", "marine natural capital,"),
"  and ",tags$a(href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/334250681_Marine_Net_Gain_Moving_towards_a_practical_framework_and_metric_for_the_marine_environment", "net gain."), "This tool was developed by Cefas within funding from The Crown Estate's ",tags$a(href="https://www.thecrownestate.co.uk/en-gb/what-we-do/on-the-seabed/offshore-wind-evidence-and-change-programme/", "Offshore Wind Evidence and Change Programme."))
#p("This tool was developed by Cefas within funding from The Crown Estate's ",tags$a(href="https://www.thecrownestate.co.uk/en-gb/what-we-do/on-the-seabed/offshore-wind-evidence-and-change-programme/", "Offshore Wind Evidence and Change Programme."))
## Header: How to use this app

h3("How to use this app",style=c("color:#044D94"))
p("Using the drop-down boxes on the left of the screen, select a category of modelled layer (currently Structure or Species distibution model (SDM)). Next select an individual layer to display.","The map window will then update. On the right of the screen are various tabs for model outputs (see table below). These are technical in nature and aimed at users with knowledge of the modelling approaches used.")

##############################
tabexplan <- data.frame(
  Tab=c("Layer Info",
         "Characteristics",
               "Input data",
               "Performance",
               "Variable contribution",
               "Partial Response Curves",
               "Confidence"),
  Explanation=c("Description of the modelled layer, a reference (if appropriate), download links (if appropriate), and details of funders or partners involved in the production of the layer",
         "Modelled class characteristics (categorical data only)",
               "Map of distribution records and a histogram (numeric models) or bar chart (categorical models) for the data used in the model",
               "Various metrics of model performance, together with a confusion matrix (class models) or scatterplot (continuous models)",
               "Predictor variable contribution to the model (in the presence of all other variables)",
               "Effect each predictor variable has on the response variable. The curves are produced by varying each predictor variable over its range in turn and predicting with the model, whilst all other variables are held constant at their mean (or in the case of a factor/categorical variable, most common) value.",
               "Map showing spatial confidence in the model, based on multiple model runs. For categorical variables (e.g. faunal cluster group), the map shows confidence, with high values (darker shades) indicating areas of high confidence. For numerical variables (e.g. species abundance), the map shows the coefficient of variation (CV). In this case, high values (darker shades) indicate higher variability and thus lower confidence in the model."
               ))

## Create a table for tabs
library(knitr)
  library(kableExtra)

    kable(tabexplan, escape=FALSE,format = "html") %>%
       column_spec (1, bold = T)%>%
            kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped","hover", "condensed"))
br()

h3("Modelling approach",style=c("color:#044D94"))
knitr::include_graphics("www/modelling_infographic.png")
p("Seabed sediments, covering large parts of the continental shelf, support a huge diversity of animal life, collectively known as the ",tags$a(href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benthos", "benthos.")," These organisms play an important role in the functioning of marine ecosystems. Understanding of the benthos comes from seabed sediment samples collected using ",tags$i("inter alia"),"grab, core and trawl devices. These samplers, deployed from survey vessles, bring back material which is then processed, resulting in a species-by-sample matrix for counts and/or biomass. Resulting data are typically used to generate ",tags$a(href="http://www.coastalwiki.org/wiki/Measurements_of_biodiversity", "biodiversity indices,"),
"the simplest of which include number of taxa and abundance. In addition, data can also put through a clustering process to identify groups of samples which support a similar complement of animals, otherwise known as an assemblage. Thus we know a lot about the benthos at these point sampled locations. However, even with the 44,603 grab and core samples available through the",tags$a(href="https://sway.office.com/HM5VkWvBoZ86atYP?ref=Link/", "OneBenthic")," big data initiative (Jan 2022), this still only equates to 4,4603 m",tags$sup("2"),", approximately two thirds the area of a football pitch. In order to make informed decisions around marine licensing and conservation, it's vital that there is an understanding of seabed biodiversity across all areas, not just those where we have data. This is where modelling comes in.")

p("Here's how it works. We start with a variety of maps for different environmental variables which are considered to be important for the benthos (e.g. depth, temperature, salinity, sediment type). These layers are called",tags$b("predictor variables")," and are available in raster format. Rasters are simply gridded maps in which each grid cell contains a value. For a full list of the raster predictor layers used for modelling see the ",tags$b("Data tab."),"Next the point sample data ", tags$b("(response variable)")," are split into 'train' and 'test' subsets. The test subset is held back from modelling and used to assess model performance (i.e how well it represents reality). Train data are overlaid on the raster stack of predictor layers. Looking down through the stack we then extract values for each predictor variable. Thus we have a good understanding of the environmental conditions associated with point sample response variable(s). Note that the point sample data could be counts or classes. We then use this understandning to look back up through the raster stack and predict what the response variable is likely to be in places where we have no point sample data. The models presented in this tool were producd using a ",tags$a(href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_forest", "Random Forest approach.")," The process is repeated with different subsets of train and test data, resulting in ten versions of the model. Different model outputs are then compared. Where there is agreement between model runs then this gives high confidence. Where models differ then we have less confidence. The test set is then overlaid on the final consensus model output to determine performance. For a more in depth description of the methodology see ", tags$a(href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2018.07.014", "here."))

#######################

Users are advised to check data with the original source, and to critically assess whether data and data products are fit for the user's intended purpose.")

p("Get in touch to tell us how you've used the app, or to report technical issues (Email: keith.cooper@cefas.co.uk / anna.downie@cefas.co.uk)")

list("Partial response curves show the effect each predictor variable has on the response variable. The curves are produced by varying each predictor variable over its range in turn and predicting with the model, whilst all other variables are held constant at their mean (or in the case of a factor variable, most common) value. Holding all other variables at a constant value is important to consider when interpreting the plots.       addPolygons(data=sac,color = "#444444", weight = 1, smoothFactor = 0.5,group = "sac",popup = paste0("<b>Name: </b>", sac$site_name))%>%
      addPolygons(data=ncmpa,color = "#444444", weight = 1, smoothFactor = 0.5,group = "ncmpa",popup = paste0("<b>Name: </b>", ncmpa$site_name))%>%
      addPolygons(data=oga,color = "#444444", weight = 1, smoothFactor = 0.5,group = "oga",popup = paste0("<b>Number: </b>", oga$licref, "<br>","<b>Organisation: </b>", oga$licorggrp))%>%
    ##################################
    addRasterImage(reactiveRaster_cv(),col=reactiveColour_cv(),opacity = 1,project = 3857)%>% 
    addLegend(
  position = "bottomright",
  pal = reactiveColour_cv(),
  opacity = 5, 
  values = c(0,0.10,0.25,0.5,1), 
  #title = "Lagis koreni CV")%>%
   title = reactivetitle())%>%
    ##################################
    addLayersControl(
      overlayGroups = c("samples","euowf","owf","owf_cab","R4_chara","R4_bid","agg","disp","wave","tidal","tidal_cab","oga","mcz","sac","ncmpa"),options = layersControlOptions(collapsed = FALSE))%>%#,"wave_cab"
      hideGroup(c("samples","euowf","owf","owf_cab","R4_chara","R4_bid","agg","disp","wave","tidal","tidal_cab","oga","mcz","sac","ncmpa"))%>%#,"wave_cab"
      #setView(-3,54.6,zoom=5.6)
    setView(0.54,55.53,zoom=5.3)%>%
    addMouseCoordinates()
  
})
